item.title: Modeling the trajectory of a spinning tennis ball using gravity, drag and the Magnus effect
item.dc:creator: Matthew Q
item.description:
Summary

This project will simulate the flight of a tennis ball under physical forces, with primarily focusing on how the spin influences its trajectory. Through the use of computational physics, I will numerically integrate the equation of motion for the ball while accounting for air resistance, gravity and the Magnus force caused by the topspin or backspin of the ball. Specifically, the simulation will demonstrate time dependent trajectories for tennis balls with different initial speeds, spin rates and launch angles. I will then generate plots in order to show visualizations of these paths. This will be useful in being able to compare how spin affects range, height and curvature to show how professional tennis players utilize spin to control the landing of their shots in the court.

Motivation

It is commonly known by tennis players that topspin causes the ball to dip more quickly and land safely inside the court while backspin will likely keep the ball floating in the air and out of the court boundary. A computational approach is needed to integrate the equations of motion and demonstrate the movement of the tennis ball. The equations of motion with relation to drag and the Magnus force are complex and nonlinear. Through simulating the ball’s motion with numerical integration in python, I can analyze different parameters such as different spins, speed and angles to generate precise trajectories. This can possibly be done using Euler methods of integration.

##Results

The computation will answer the questions about using different spin rates and how it changes it trajectory. Through numerically solving differential equations for position and velocity, I will be able to visualize and distinguish differences between topspin, backspin and no spin shots. The model will show how high the ball goes above a normal tennis net, how far it travels before landing and how quickly it curves downward. These results will consist of how air drag and gravity depend on velocity magnitude, range and direction. I expect the simulation to show that topspin creates an evidently faster downward curvature, while backspin creates a longer and slower path. The graphs that will be included will be trajectory vs time, landing position and velocity changes. These graphs will ultimately demonstrate the role of spin in shot control.

Summary/Questions

How much earlier does a topspin shot dip toward the court compared to a flat shot and backspin shot?

How does the spin rate of a tennis ball influence its trajectory, in terms of range maximum height and curvature?

How do different spin rates affect landing position?

For a given initial speed and launch angle, how much does adding topspin or backspin change where the ball lands?

I expect to find that topspin reduces the horizontal distance traveled and increases the downward acceleration, while backspin increases flight time and trajectory height. I will compare my simulated trajectories with online experimental data possibly from sports science research. This will prove if my model generates realistic trajectories and if landing spots are accurately predicted.

Comment

This is a good project that takes the trajectory and drag force to simulate tennis. The Magnus force is implemented from the rotation of the ball and the velocity .

Once the initial conditions are given, this can be implemented and solved in different scenarios.

You can compute the trajectory, but also the horizontal range, the maximum height of the tennis ball and how long it takes. You can compare these values with the actual values and also graph them as a function of some initial condition (such as the initial speed).

item.title: Hohmann Transfer Visualization from Earth to Mars via Continous TMI Burn
item.dc:creator: Chenchu
item.description:
Summary

This project models an Earth-to-Mars Hohmann transfer using a continuous trans-Mars injection (TMI) burn instead of an idealized instantaneous Hohmann impulse.

During the gradual buildup of velocity, Earth’s and the Sun’s gravity continuously act on the spacecraft, warping its trajectory away from the simple analytical ellipse predicted by an ideal impulse. These overlapping gravitational and thrust effects make the motion impossible to solve analytically, requiring step-by-step numerical integration.

This simulation helps illustrate how real interplanetary transfers differ from the idealized models often used in theory. This simulation helps illustrate how real interplanetary transfers differ from the idealized models often used in theory.

Motivation/Background/Question

The traditional Hohmann transfer is an idealistic method to plan trajectories for a spacecraft to move from one orbit to another, assuming idealistic and instantaneous burns which simply cannot exist in reality. Spacecraft accelerate gradually over time while being acting upon the gravitation influences of nearby bodies, in our case being the Sun and Earth, in turn preventing the perfect elliptical trajectories predicted by Hohmann transfers.

During a continuous burn, thrust is pushing in one direction while gravity from Earth and the Sun is pulling in another, these two forces act at the same time continuous along with the change in the spacecraft’s velocity, preventing a simple analytical solution.

Hohmann transfers are used in orbital dynamics to calculate the most fuel efficient setups (the lowest needed ) to move between two orbits while also being more simple to calculate. In real Mars transfer missions, Hohmann transfers serve as a baseline to plan missions initially but must be built upon to account for gravity losses during finite burns, planer changes requiring more and margins of safety given the likelihood of delays or errors within burns.

To do this, we will have to numerically integrate the Spacecraft’s position and velocity over time.

Results

From my research regarding the numerical approach for this problem the given spacecraft’s position “x”, velocity “v” and mass “m” evolve as such:

T = Thrust, is direction and is the Sun’s gravitational parameter.

As seen, due to how m, v and change over time, an analytical solution for x(t) and v(t) is not possible.

Therefore I will be utalizing a numerical method called “Runge - Kutta” to calculate the trajectory for each step, more steps meaning the higher the resolution and more accurate my predicted path. This will at the end of the day help me achieve my actual goal of understanding how Thrust and gravitational forces on the spacecraft interact with each other through the burn, as well as help me understand the change in predicted by Hohmann as compared to integrating over time for a more accurate value.

Summary/Questions

This project aims to answer how a continuous TMI burn changes a spacecraft’s trajectory compared to the ideal Hohmann transfer that assumes instantaneous burns. I expect to find that continuous thrust causes gravity losses, requiring slightly more and altering the transfer time. The simulation should show how the gradual acceleration bends the spacecraft’s path away from the perfect elliptical orbit predicted analytically.

Comparable data can be drawn from published Hohmann transfer values for Earth–Mars missions, which serve as a baseline for validating the analytical results. For the numeral analysis I will draw from the launch C3 of real mars missions via JPL’s public press kits, I’ll use the C3 to compute the impulsive TMI from parking orbit and then will compare that to my continuous burn results.

item.title: Dielectric Variations of a DBD Plasma Actuator in a Conductive Box
item.dc:creator: Matthew F
item.description:
Summary Paragraph

A Dielectric Barrier Discharge (DBD) plasma actuator operates by applying a high-voltage, high-frequency AC signal across two electrodes separated by a dielectric barrier. When the applied voltage reaches the breakdown threshold of air, a localized, non-thermal plasma is generated. The actuator’s asymmetric electrode configuration—one exposed and one buried—produces a net electrohydrodynamic (EHD) body force directed along the surface from the exposed electrode. Because the discharge is non-thermal, DBD actuators are energy-efficient and can safely operate at atmospheric pressure, making them attractive for flow control, propulsion, and surface treatment applications. However, in practical configurations, nearby conductive surfaces can alter the electric field distribution, charge accumulation, and resulting plasma behavior. To better understand these effects, this study employs numerical simulations to vary both the dielectric thickness and the size of the surrounding conductive box. The results will quantify how these parameters influence charge density, electric field strength, potential distribution, and overall actuator performance. In particular, increasing box size will help determine the distance at which conductive boundaries cease to affect the plasma region, while varying dielectric thickness will reveal trade-offs between breakdown voltage, power deposition, and plasma uniformity. The expected outcome is that thicker dielectrics reduce electric field intensity and plasma strength, while sufficiently large enclosures produce negligible influence beyond a critical dimension.

Motivation / Background / Question

  • A DBD (dielectric barrier discharge) plasma actuator operates by applying a high-voltage, high-frequency AC signal across two electrodes separated by a dielectric barrier. The voltage reaches the breakdown threshold of air, partially ionizing it and creating a local cold (non-thermal) plasma. One electrode is exposed to the air while the other is embedded beneath the dielectric; this geometric asymmetry generates a net electrohydrodynamic (EHD) body force directed outward along the surface from the exposed electrode.

  • Because the discharge is non-thermal, DBD actuators are energy-efficient and can operate safely at atmospheric pressure. Their combination of ionic wind generation and reactive plasma chemistry enables applications across multiple domains.

  • In practice, plasma actuators are often enclosed or positioned near conductive surfaces, which can influence the electric field distribution, charge accumulation, and consequently the induced body force. Understanding how dielectric thickness and conductive enclosure size affect plasma generation and actuator efficiency is difficult to isolate experimentally, making computational modeling a crucial approach.

Results:

  • Through numerical simulations, the study will systematically vary the dielectric thickness and the size of the surrounding conductive box to evaluate their effects on plasma characteristics—such as charge density, electric field strength, and potential distribution. * Increasing the box size will help determine the spatial extent at which the enclosure no longer influences the plasma region, while dielectric thickness variations will reveal the trade-off between breakdown voltage, power deposition, and actuator efficiency.

  • These results require a computational approach because of the complex coupling between electrostatics, plasma chemistry, and geometry-dependent boundary conditions that are not easily captured analytically.

Summary / Questions

  • This work aims to answer: How does dielectric thickness influence the plasma strength and uniformity of a DBD actuator? and At what enclosure size does the conductive boundary cease to affect plasma performance?
  • The expected outcome is that thicker dielectrics will reduce electric field strength and thus lower plasma intensity, while sufficiently large conductive boxes will have negligible influence beyond a critical dimension.

Comments

The full model might be quite complex, so will be best to focus on a particular aspect; also keep in mind that this has to be explained to an audience in a brief amount of time. It is suitable for numerical computation.

  • what are the boundary conditions in this problem?

  • how is the breakdown threshold of air determined or implemented?

  • how can the problem be simplified further to make it more fitting for the class, distill the basics, and focus on the educational portion rather than the research portion?

item.title: Using the Fourier Transform to Filter Noise from an ECG Signal
item.dc:creator: Kristy
item.description:
Summary

This project will use the Fourier transform to clean noise from an electrocardiogram (ECG) signal. ECG signals measure electrical activity of the heart, but in real life situations they often contain noise from breathing, electrical interference, and most of all movement. In this project I will generate a simple ECG-like signal, add artificial noise, and then use the Fourier transform to filter the noise.

Background

ECGs are one of the most used diagnostic tools in medicine. Proper preparations aim to limit noise but the raw signal almost always contains some unwanted noise. According to a technical guide from GE HealthCare, this noise can come from fluorescent light, cell phoones, Bluetooth devices, or physical movement of a patient. A review by Luo & Johnston (2010) explains that ECG filtering is an essential preprocessing step. Noise can hide features like the P wave, QRS complex, and T wave. They also discuss how different types of noise require different filtering strategies, and how filtering must be done carefully to avoid the diagnostic information.

The Fourier transform is a common way to separate a signal into its frequency components. This can aid in removing noise such as 60 Hz power-line interference. Because an ECG consists of a lot of data points, and filtering involves modifying the whole frequency spectrum, a computational approach is a fitting practical method.

Results

I expect to make several plots showing 3 things: a clean ECG-like signal, a noisy version after adding interference, the filtered signal after operating the Fourier transform.
Before filtering I expect to see a dominant frequency that simulates a heartbeat along with noise components. After filtering, the inverse Fourier transform should reconstruct it to look like the original clean signal.

A basic ECG waveform contains a big number of time points, and the Fourier transform formula alone requires combining every point using exponentials. Each component is computed using a sum over the entire signal, meaning lots of work. Also, the output of the transform should be interpreted visually and without a computer we cannot picture the signal by looking at numbers.

Summary/Questions

The specific question this project aims to answer is:

  • “Can the Fourier transform effectively isolate and recover a heartbeat signal from noisy ECG data?”

I expect the filtered signal to closely resemble the clean waveform before noise was added. Similar results are reported in ECG-filtering research like that of Luo & Johnston (2010), where frequency-based filtering is shown to be effective for removing power-line and baseline-wander noise. My project is a simplified version of these real-world techniques and demonstrates the use of computational tools in the medical field.

References

  • Luo,S., & Johnston, P. (2010). A review of electrocardiogram filtering. Journal of Electrocardiology, 43(6), 486-496.
  • GE HealthCare. (2023) A guide to ECG signal filtering.

Comments

Good project with references and a clear question. The Fourier transform was not covered in the class, but NumPy provides Fourier transforms with numpy.fft.fft() The scope is reasonable and it uses numerical approaches (FFT).

item.title: Stellar Structure
item.dc:creator: Joseph
item.description:
Summary Paragraph

For my final project, I aim to investigate basic stellar structure by solving for the equations of state of a star and using the results to construct a synthetic Hertzsprung-Russell (HR) diagram. The composition of the star influences the macroscopic observables such as pressure, temperature and luminosity. Typically, hydrogen and helium dominate the composition of a star influencing its observables. The produced HR diagram will be explored by varying such conditions, specifically the mean molecular weight () and stellar mass (). The project will connect how these parameters influence the macroscopic stellar properties using numerical computation for the solutions of various () and ().

Motivation / Background / Question :

In astrophysics, the equations of stellar strucutre consist of nonlinear coupled differential equations that cannot be solved analytically. These equations describe hydrostatic equilibrium, mass continuity, luminosty and energy generation. The importance of such equations is to link thermodynamic quantities to the macroscopic observables such as luminosity, radius of the star, and surface temperature. Here, the mean molecular weight is a key parameter in the equation of state as it sets the conditions for the pressure and temperature required to support a given stellar mass. Changes in will alter , and . Because of the nonlinear coupling of these equations, numerical integration is required to explore how stellar properties depend on their internal composition.

Results

By numerically integrating the stellar structure equations for stars of varying mass and mean molecular weight, I expect to produce a value for the density, temperaure, pressure and luminosity for each model. From this, I aim to plot a collection of synthetic data on the HR diagram. I anticipate that increasing at some fixed stellar mass will increase the central temperature and luminoisty, shifting stars upward on the HR diagram. Similary, increaing stellar mass I anticipate will produce hotter and more luminous stars, hence shifting the stars upward on the HR diagram as well. Numerical compuataion is essential for this project because of the coupled ODEs being nonlinear and dependent on both and , preventing me from solving these analytically.

Summary/Question

The central question guiding the project is: How do variations in stellar composition () and stellar mass () affect the predicted properties and HR diagram position of stars? I expect to find that higher μ increases the central temperature, nuclear energy generation rate, and luminosity, producing shifts in the HR diagram. Increasing mass will have a similar effect, producing hotter, brighter stars. These synthetic results will be compared qualitatively with observed main-sequence stars and known empirical scaling laws, illustrating how the microscopic physics propagates to macroscopic observable star behavior.

Comments

  • Make simplifications; emissivity = 1, etc.

item.title: Fractal Gravity
item.dc:creator: Gavin
item.description:
Summary

This project aims to simulate the gravitational field that would arise if one assigns mass to the components of a fractal set. To accomplish this, the dimension of the fractal must be finite, thus the perimeter of the fractal must be approximated with a finite number of interactions. Either a Koch Snowflake, the Mandelbrot set, the Julia set, or the Burning Ship fractals will be used as the set. The gravitational field must be assigned based on a fractal density function that will be influenced by the chosen resolution of the fractal’s perimeter. An arbitrarily scaled mass is assigned to each point in the set, then the density function is applied, then the resulting gravitational field is calculated.

If time permits, the behavior of a point particle within the vicinity of the set will be investigated and used to drive a subsidiary fractal. Each point in the finite perimeter is assigned a ‘color’ varying from each end of the visual spectrum. The path of the particle subject to the graviational field will be calculated for varying initial position and velocities, indexed by some . Iterating thrugh this process, the first point at which the particle’s position is equal to a point in the set, the color of this point will be assigned to that specific . Next, all points will be plotted on a phase space plot of vs with their assigned color. Depending on the behavior of the fractal’s gravitational field, this phase space plot my resemble ‘fractal’ like patterns.

Motivation / Background / Question

Fractal billiards is the most closely related field of study. Typically perfeclty elastic particles (billiards) are placed within a fractal, treating the points along it’s boundary as a rigid barrier. Assigning the billiards some mass, initial position, and initial speed, their kinematics are analyzed for patterns. As far as I am aware, no study has assigned the fractal itself a mass. I believe it may be interesting to see what kind of gravitational field arises from the fractal’s underlying pattern. It could be a trivial one, with the ‘center of mass’ as the center of a radial field, however when accounting for the varying density of a fractal set, I believe the resulting field could be non-trivial and thus give rise to interesting dynamics.

The definition of a fractal requires that it be an infinitely complex and self similar pattern, meaning one may never calculate a fractal to it’s ‘full’ extent. This means computationally, the fractal must be approximated to some finite degree which introduces a need for numerical methods.

Results:

I intend to show the gravitational vector field that arises from the fractal. This must be calculated numerically as the fractal is being approximated to a finite degree and can no longer be treated analytically.

If time permits, I intend to create the phase space plot of the partile’s behavior as described above. This does pose a significant computational challenge as the resolution of the indexing for the position and velocity will weight heavily on computation time. The current structure of this approach essentially will require two embedded for loops for the indices, then a third embedded while loop for the path calculation. Depending on how computationally expensive this becomes, the approach may have to be reconfigured, or a degree of freedom may be removed (i.e. fixing initial speed).

Questions

This project aims to answer two main questions:

  • Does assigning mass to a fractal produce a nontrivial gravitational field?
  • Do the kinematics of a point particle within the vicinity of a fractal with mass give rise to a subsidiary fractal?

As these questions have not yet been explored (as far as I am aware), data does not yet exist for the results of this project to be compared to. Somewhat similar procedures for calculating subsidiary fractals have been carried out for systems like the three body problem and a ball bouncing within a semi circle. In all known cases, however, the applied field was some analog of a radially inward gravitational field.

Comments

  • Which fractal will you use?

  • How is exactly is the fractal defined? Which one are you using, will you calculate the gravitational field on a 2D raster? Will you compare the fractal to a non-fractal, say a disk?

  • How large is your 2D grid?

  • For the computation it is best to do it in dimensionless units. You need some normalization or density without units. Therefore, define the gravitational interaction in terms of unitless parameters. Distance will then be measured as part of the grid.

  • How will you visualize your results? Contour plots?

item.title: The 3 body problem
item.dc:creator: Victoria G and Ivy
item.description:
The 3 body problem takes real data, our orbital diagram of the known solar system, and applies a hypothetical question, what would our Earth look like with 3 masses orbiting Earth itself?

My motivation itself came from one of my favorite book series The 3 body problem. It takes this idea and explores what different ‘Earths’ would look like, not just in the broader sense, but looks at the climate, what would be considered normal? How would the Sun rise and set? This is my main source of inspiration. While orbits of the solar system has been studied since man first looked up, it was always us orbiting something else, well except for that hiccup in the old times, I am looking at you Eudoxus and Ptolmey with your geocentic theory. Well, I wanted to take what we know about our heliocentric solar system and see what it would take for 3 masses, including the moon, and how it would effect the Earth. Effect the Earth in the way of could it be feasible, how large would the masses have to be, or small, to keep a habital condition here on Earth. This would require a computational approach in more ways then one. It would take the basis of what we know about Newtonian mechanics, which we CAN solve analytically. This idea becomes interesting by that special component of adding a third body, this then turns our approach into a ‘coupled nonlinear differential equation’, which I am currently learning about in my numerical analysis class. Initial conditions would lead to chaotic behavior, and an analytical approach would simply, not be able to keep up.

This would require pulling my skill sets from past and present classes, including but not limited to; Computational Physics, Analytic Mechanics, Numerical Analysics, Differentional Equations A & B and others. In the extremely basic expectation, I expect larger masses to completely destroy this model, my end result existing in an simulation where Earth would not be habital, gravitational forces itself would not make this possible. I expect possible smaller masses to potentially make this model possible, however how small would be the real finding. More digging would have to be done to see if there was comparable data out there, that would either lead me to believe my findings were heading in the right direction or not.

Comments

Great concept, the question and scope needs to be sharpened at this moment. For example, what is “habitability”? Is that defined by temperature, distance, etc? What masses, initial positions and velocities will be probed. The phase space can get very large, since we have 3 bodies, it means 9 starting positions (assuming planets are in one plane). Maybe keep 1 body constant.

What is stability? Sometimes it may orbit a few times, then a planet will go off. Sometimes, numerical precision limits the orbit.

Start with a simple system, using realistic parameters, make sure that your numbers are not too small or too large.

Use energy conservation to make sure that your computation is not running afoul of basic laws. (Issue with the Euler method).

Best would be to change one parameter at a time, so need to choose which one? Starting position of the moon?

item.title: Modeling and Visualizing a Binary Black Hole Chirp
item.dc:creator: Said
item.description:
In this project I will attempt to simulate a gravitational wave chirp signal which is produced by two merging black holes. I can compare it to data from LIGOs detections to see how close my simulation is. Using NumPy, SciPy, and Matplotlib, I will model the inspiral phase using a Newtonian model with gravitational wave energy loss. I want to visualize the resulting waveform, spectrogram, and orbital motion.

Gravitational waves come from accelerating massive bodies, the binary black holes produce very strong and measurable signals. As they lose energy to radiation their orbits tighten and frequency increases creating the chirp. Because the system evolves nonlinearly I will need numerical integration to generate the waveform to compare with real data.

My expected results would include the simulated chirp waveform that increases in both amplitude and frequency also a spectrogram showing the time frequency evolution. And an orbital animation of the merging system to visualize what is happening.

My main question is “Can a simplified model produce the features of a real binary black hole chirp?” I expect the data to match somewhat, and there is comparable data available.

Comments

Do you start with point sources? There is a lot of data for this kind of problem available.

  • What starting conditions will you use? What are the initial masses? What are the quantities that you will be using? Can you make them dimensionless for the computation?

  • What is the initial separation distance?

The challenge is to implement the energy loss model. Much of that work is though analytical, not numerical. What is the numerical work that you can do?

Are you using Newtonian gravity?

Will you animate the result?

What data from LIGO can you use for the comparison?
